results.firPara: Got a minute? Digest the best of our latest coverage from Euro 2016 as Wales prepare for the biggest match of their lives against Portugal
results.webTitle: The Euro 2016 minute: Cymru am byth!

results.firPara: Vladimir Putins spokesman has attacked a lavish Monte Carlo party attended by two Russia players days after their Euro 2016 failure as a shameless display of conceit.
results.secPara: Video posted online shows the players – the forward Aleksandr Kokorin and the midfielder Pavel Mamaev – at the Twiga nightclub surrounded by champagne and sparklers as Russias national anthem plays in the background.
results.webTitle: Russia players deny spending €250,000 on champagne after Euro 2016 exit

results.firPara: • Barcelona forward not expected to serve any of sentence
results.secPara: Lionel Messi and his father Jorge have been sentenced to 21 months in prison for tax fraud, but the Barcelona forward is not expected to spend any time behind bars.
results.webTitle: Lionel Messi handed 21-month tax fraud sentence but is unlikely to serve time

results.firPara: The midfielder, who was part of the Greece team that won the Euros 12 years ago, talks about the secrets of their success and when they started to believe they could win the tournament
results.secPara: Twelve years ago Greece stunned everyone by winning the European Championship, lifting the trophy at the Estádio da Luz in Lisbon with the city becoming a Greek colony for a few days. In the streets of Portugals capital – as well as back in Athens – fans were rejoicing and singing in honour of Piratiko, the Pirate Ship, as a famous radio commentator had nicknamed the team.
results.webTitle: Greece’s Giorgos Karagounis: ‘Wales have the belief, just like we did in 2004’

results.firPara: Most of the players who have played this year are locks for the Olympic roster, and coach Jill Ellis rarely experiments – because she doesnt need to
results.secPara: Most of the players who have played this year are locks for the Olympic roster, and coach Jill Ellis rarely experiments – because she doesnt need to
results.webTitle: Why competition for places is so fierce on the US women's national team

results.firPara: West Bromwich Albion have confirmed that the Scotland winger Matt Phillips has become their first new signing of the summer for an undisclosed fee believed to be around £6m.
results.secPara: Phillips, who moved to Queens Park Rangers in 2013 from Blackpool, has agreed a four-year contract and will join his new team-mates for the pre-season fitness camp in Austria.
results.webTitle: West Brom confirm signing of Matt Phillips from QPR for £6m

results.firPara: Stoke City are close to agreeing a deal with the Egyptian club Al Ahly to sign the highly-rated teenager Ramadan Sobhi, with the forward expected to join for an initial fee of around £2.5m.
results.secPara: Sobhi, 19, was a regular in the Ahly side who won the Egyptian title last month under the former Tottenham and Fulham manager Martin Jol, scoring five goals.
results.webTitle: Stoke close to signing Egypt winger Ramadan Sobhi from Al Ahly

results.firPara: AZ Alkmaar have thrown Tottenhams move for Vincent Janssen into doubt after their sporting director revealed they have yet to receive an improved bid for the Holland striker.
results.secPara: The 22-year-old, who finished as the top scorer in the Dutch league last season with 27 goals in 32 appearances, was the subject of a bid worth €18m (£16.5m) from Spurs last month, which was rejected. That led Janssen to voice his frustration at their stance, with AZ believed to be holding out for a fee of €20m – reportedly on the advice of the subject of Michael Lewiss best-selling book Moneyball, Billy Beane, who was hired as an adviser in March last year.
results.webTitle: ‘The store does not belong to you’: no new Tottenham bid for Janssen

results.firPara: The Wales manager was seemingly made for international football and even as a player tended to come into his own on matchdays
results.secPara: Regardless of how Euro 2016 ends, Chris Colemans status as a Welsh hero is secure. But it all very nearly unravelled, back in September 2012, when mere qualification for a major tournament looked distant, never mind reaching the semi-finals. That was when Wales lost 6-1 to Serbia during World Cup qualification, and Coleman seriously considered leaving the post he had taken eight months earlier. I had doubts whether I was capable of doing the job, he said last year. We didnt just lose in Serbia, we embarrassed ourselves. But I think Id have been a bit of a coward if Id walked away.
results.webTitle: Chris Coleman has the happy knack of delivering with Wales | Nick Miller
